prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral averaging factor of 8 in FDM is more than sufficient to reach our 50 km/s effective spectral resolution.

These data will be compared with VLT/MUSE optical spectroscopy, which has a seeing requirement of 1.2". This requires the C36-3 configuration. The C36-2 configuration would be an acceptable alternative.
Although the first 2 of our main science goals can be reached with only the 12m array, adding the ACA would allow to also reach our 3rd goal, viz. detecting the very diffuse molecular gas.

We base our line estimate on previous [CI](1-0) detections in unlensed submm galaxies, which are 0.5-1.0 Jy.km/s. To account for spatially extended emission of up to 5 synthesized beams, we aim to reach a 3sigma limit of 0.1 Jy.km/s.
As we are interested in tracing the narrow 50 km/s primordial gas, we use this for our adopted bandwidth. Note that the active regions can be an order of magnitude broader, which would allow to derive velocity gradients in our data.
The spectral averaging factor of 8 in FDM is more than sufficient to reach our 50 km/s effective spectral resolution.

These data will be compared with VLT/MUSE optical spectroscopy, which has a seeing requirement of 1.2", which we relax to 1.35" to avoid a time-consuming compact 12m array observation. This requires the C36-3 configuration. The C36-2 configuration would be an acceptable alternative.
Although the first 2 of our main science goals can be reached with only the 12m array, adding the ACA would allow to also reach our 3rd goal, viz. detecting the very diffuse molecular gas.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent VLT/MUSE observations of the extended (>100 kpc) gaseous haloes surrounding high-redshift radio galaxies have revealed a very complex structure of ionized and neutral gas. A comparison with our snapshot ALMA Cycle 1 + 2 dust continuum imaging shows that the star-formation in these haloes can be offset by as much as 80 kpc from the central AGN. We here propose matched resolution ALMA [CI](1-0) imaging of a sample of seven radio galaxies at 2.9<z<4.6 which are optimally observable with both MUSE and ALMA. The [CI] line is a unique tracer of the H_2 gas, arguably even more reliable than the classical low-J CO lines. Combining the ALMA [CI] and MUSE datasets will provide a complete picture of the molecular, neutral and ionized gas surrounding these massive galaxies in the making where primordial gas accretion and AGN feedback are observed in action.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research
Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Johns Hopkins University
Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), California Institute of Technology
